div1.p: Abstract of Contents Enclosing translation of Govenor General's Despatch relating to Fees and Charges on Whaling Vessels
div1.note: (Copied for Bu. Statutes Yrr 10th 1881.) Compared with Copy for publication in Consular Rules No 13. Nov. 16.1881
div1.p: United States Consulate St Paul de Loanda 16th September 1881

Sir, I have the honor to enclose a translation of a Despatch received from His Excellency the Governor General of this Province in reply to my request to reduce the Fees and Charges levied on Whaling Vessels sowing to this port. You will notice by the translation that His Excellency has kindly granted my request, and that now the charges are so moderate that I should think it would not keep vessels from coming to a port where they will find greater facilities in arranging Provinces or any thing they may require, than in any other port on
on the coast.
I have the honor to be Sir Your most Obedient Servant Rob S. Newton Vice Consel
To the Assistant Secretary of State Washington D.C.
Translation of Governor General Dantes's Despatch dated 3rd August 1881.
In answer to your Despatch dated the 14th July, His Excellency the Governor General has ordered me to communicate the following:--

1st that Whalers are allowed to come into port for the span of 6 days or for a longer time when requested, free of all expenses with the exception of 400 Reis or 40 cents a day while in port; for a Custom House Guard and 1500 Reis or 1.62 Cents for the Health Vesel; all the captain of the Port charges will be 1,500 Reis or 1.62 Cents for bringing the ship into port, and 1,500 Reis or 1.62 cents for beer pilotage
Pilotage out.

2nd That the said Whalers can Store their Oil in the Custom House, paying 2% ad valorem on re-shipment; keeping it in the Custom House for another 6 months it will pay 20 Reis or 2 cents for ever 10 letres. Ships gear etc. stored in the Custom House are free from their last charge. You must take note that these advantages are only valid in the Loanda Custom House, not at those of Massamedes and Benguella, as they are not deposit Custom Houses, and are not adapted to store large quantities of Cash.
3rd Lastly, Whalers can receive Provisions etc from the ships that come usually every 6 months from America with their supplies, trans-shipping Oil to them without paying any duties whatever.

In case you have any remarks
remarks to make on what His Excellency the Governor General has ordered me to communicate to you, will you kindly do so, as His Excellency is willing to do all in his power, within the Law, to facilitate Whalers coming into this port, and harmonising the interests of these with the Laws to which they are subject
signed João José da Silva Acting Secretary
To the Vice Consul of the United States St Paul de Loanda.
